Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Robust and Secure Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cognitive radio is a promising paradigm for dramatically increasing the utilization of wireless spectrum to support the continuing exponential growth in wireless traffic. Research on cognitive networks has mainly focused on sensing of spectrum opportunities and managing radio resources such that the primary users' quality of service is not compromised. Much less attention has been paid to the coexistence of secondary users, which may be associated with different cognitive networks and seek to operate in the same frequency bands. Effective coexistence of such users is essential for the success of future cognitive networks, and is the main objective of this project. In addition, the particularly open nature of cognitive radio raises significant new issues for the security and privacy of the transmitted data, as well as new opportunities for malicious behavior among cognitive or outside entities. The project addresses all of these issues in a holistic framework.

Coexistence requires effective allocation of radio resources in time, frequency, and space among multiple cognitive secondary users, while respecting primary interference constraints. The investigators are developing theoretical bounds for such radio resource management schemes and designing low-overhead distributed algorithms, which account for the incentives of competing secondary service providers as well as the stronger security and privacy measures needed in a cognitive environment. Information-theoretic physical-layer security techniques are being utilized to develop provably secure paradigms for secondary cognitive users and game-theoretic models are being adapted to study the robustness of these networks to various jamming attacks and other malicious behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a collaborative project as part of the Wireless Innovation between Finland and U.S. (WiFiUS) virtual institute. The project was a collaboration between PIs at Northwestern University and the University of Maryland in the U.S. and Aalto University and Oulu University in Finland with the goal of studying aspects of cognitive radio networks.  The main tasks undertaken at Northwestern as part of this collaboration were (1) to develop low overhead distributed radio resource allocation algorithms for cognitive networks and (2) to develop and study models that account for the economic incentives of secondary service providers.

For the first task, along with our collaborators we developed new distributed pricing algorithms for allocating radio resources. These algorithms extended existing algorithms to account for new objectives (such as minimizing transmit power) and to accommodate various physical layer enhancements (such as allowing for cooperative transmission). We also studied game theoretic approaches to distributed resource allocation both in the case where users can employ any information theoretic optimal strategy and in cases where they have technology limits. In both cases we characterized the resulting equilibria and gained insights into the behavior of selfish users in such settings.

For the second task, we extended previous work on price competition among service providers to settings where various forms of cognitive sharing are used. In such setting we again formulated a game among competing cognitive service providers and characterized the resulting equilibrium. The analysis sheds light on how different forms of cognitive sharing interact with the profit seeking behavior of service providers.
